column7: If exponent is 0 generators are distributed evenly across the region, if it is 1 they are distributed proportional to capacity factor, if it is x they are distributed proportional to (capacity factor)^x
n-hourly, n<3 is very slow, big n solves faster (n=25 or n=49 give fast and relatively accurate results)
Demand should be large enough for utility-scale assets but small enough to neglect land availability constraints

column7: [^mitchell2019]: Mitchell, C., Avagyan, V., Chalmers, H., & Lucquiaud, M. (2019). An initial assessment of the value of Allam Cycle power plants with liquid oxygen storage in future GB electricity system. International Journal of Greenhouse Gas Control, 87, 1–18. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijggc.2019.04.020

column6: Estimate, based on a value from [^hu2013], which states 320 EUR-2012/m3 incl. installation but based on a single supply quote for 2500 m3 tank installation; 320 EUR/m3 / 1,142 t/m3_O2(l) * (1,03 inflation per year)^(8 years) = 355 EUR-2020/t_O2(l); to be on safe side, assume here 400 EUR-2020/t. [^hanak2017] also suggest a scaling factor of 0.6 which we neglect here, so value here might be significantly overestimating (3-4x) for large storage tanks >10kt O2 (l) storing capacity.
column7: [^hanak2017]: Hanak, D. P., Powell, D., & Manovic, V. (2017). Techno-economic analysis of oxy-combustion coal-fired power plant with cryogenic oxygen storage. Applied Energy, 191, 193–203. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apenergy.2017.01.049 , [^hu2013]: Hu, Y., Li, X., Li, H., & Yan, J. (2013). Peak and off-peak operations of the air separation unit in oxy-coal combustion power generation systems. Applied Energy, 112, 747–754. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apenergy.2012.12.001

column6: Daily cryogenic evaporation losses from oxygen storage, suggested 0.05-0.1%/d by Teichgraeber, H., Brodrick, P. G., & Brandt, A. R. (2017). Optimal design and operations of a flexible oxyfuel natural gas plant. Energy, 141, 506–518. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.energy.2017.09.087
